Award.AwardTitle: Nonlinear Geo metric Equations of Monge-Ampere Type and Canonical Metrics
Award.AbstractNarration: Abstract<br/><br/>Award: DMS-0604805<br/>Principal Investigator: Jian Song<br/><br/>This proposal concerns existence and regularity problems of the<br/>nonlinear Monge-Ampere type equations from geometry and physics.<br/>The problem of finding canonical metrics on a compact Kahler<br/>manifold has been the subject of intense study over the last few<br/>decades. In his solution to Calabi's conjecture, Yau proved the<br/>existence of a Kahler-Einstein metric on compact Kahler manifolds<br/>with vanishing or negative first Chern class. An alternative<br/>proof of Calabi's conjecture is given by Cao using the<br/>Kahler-Ricci flow. However, most projective algebraic varieties<br/>do not have definite or trivial first Chern classes. Recently<br/>Perelman has made major breakthrough in Hamilton's program as an<br/>approach to the Poincare conjecture and Thurston's geometrization<br/>conjecture. The principal investigator proposes to study the<br/>canonical metrics on the canonical models of projective varieties<br/>of positive Kodaira dimension by applying the Kahler-Ricci<br/>flow. Such canonical metrics are constructed by the deformation<br/>of the Kaher-Ricci flow on minimal projective surfaces of<br/>positive Kodaira dimension. These generalized Kahler-Einstein<br/>metrics can be considered as an analytic version of the abundance<br/>conjecture in algebraic geometry and will also lead to new<br/>advances in the understanding and application of the Ricci<br/>flow. In Donaldson's far reaching program, the geometry of the<br/>infinite dimensional symmetric space of Kahler metrics in a fixed<br/>class is related to the existence and uniqueness of constant<br/>scalar curvature Kahler metrics. The principal investigator also<br/>intends to study the uniform approximation problem of the<br/>Monge-Ampere geodesics in infinite dimensional symmetric space by<br/>those in the finite dimensional Bergman spaces on toric<br/>varieties. The precise understanding of this problem will give<br/>new insight into the conjecture proposed by Yau between the<br/>relation of constant scalar curvature Kahler metrics and certain<br/>stability in the sense of geometric invariant theory. The<br/>principal investigator will also apply the moment map point of<br/>view and study various geometric flows arising from Kahler<br/>geometry as well as symplectic geometry proposed by<br/>Donaldson. The first is the J-flow, which is the gradient flow of<br/>functional related to the Mabuchi energy. The second is a moment<br/>map flow in a hyperkahler four manifold. The principal<br/>investigator intends to study the question of convergence and<br/>singularities os such parabolic flows.<br/><br/>Since the discovery of the general relativity, geometric analysis<br/>has become crucial to both mathematicians and physicists.<br/>Problems in this proposal arise naturally from our attempts to<br/>understand nonlinear differential equations from geometry and<br/>physics. The solutions to these problems will contribute to<br/>various fields of sciences such as physics and cosmology in the<br/>deep understanding of our universe. The method of analyzing the<br/>singularities of nonlinear equations will have wide applications<br/>in engineering and economics.<br/>
